details.abstract: The paper by Hwang (IEEE Trans. Reliability, vol. 54, no.1, p. 169-172, 2005) presented structural importance measures in terms of cutsets or pathsets, and investigated how they are related. Hwang's paper has made contributions to importance measures. However, several errors which cause confusions are found in the paper. This note is to clarify these errors, and discuss the suspicions.

references.title: A hierarchy of importance indices

context.text: To be consistent, we use and clarify the notation of [5].
Hwang [5] surveyed some importance measures proposed in the literature (see also Kuo & Zuo [7]), and proposed a new one.
Thus, [5] made important contributions to the research of importance measures.
However, several errors & suspicions are found in [5].
In [5], terms “minimal cutset (pathset)” and “minimum cutset (pathset)” and notation \$\overline{C}(\overline{P})\$ etc. and \$\tilde{C}(\tilde{P})\$ etc. are used confusingly.
In the two paragraphs following Theorem 4.3 in [5], first-term importance, and rare-event importance were defined based on minimum cutsets, and pathsets, respectively.
Except that, the rest of [5] should use the term “minimal”, and notation \$\overline{C}\$ or \$\overline{P}\$ etc. instead of “minimum”, and \$\tilde{C}\$ or \$\tilde{P}\$ etc.

Originated from Lemma 1 in [5], [6] expressed the Birnbaum importance of component \$i\$ as
 assuming \$p_{1}=p_{2}=\cdots=p_{n}=p\$.

Based on (1), [5] defined c-Birnbaum importance as
.

Because c-andp-Birnbaum importance measures are equivalent, Fig. 3 in [5] [see Fig. 2(a)], which indicates the relations of importance measures based on cutsets or pathsets, should be revised as Fig. 2(b) shown below.

Fig. 2:
A hierarchy of importance measures; (a) Fig. 3 in [5]; (b) corrected one.
A hierarchy of importance measures; (a) Fig. 3 in [5]; (b) corrected one.
Additionally, Theorem 3.6 in [5], which gives the relation of H-importance and Birnbaum importance, should be correspondingly revised.

Based on (1), which is proved to be wrong, [5] stated that the combinatorial importance, which is the Birnbaum importance when \$p=1/2\$, can be defined as \$2^{-n} (\vert P_{i}\ \vert\ - \vert P_{(i)}\vert)\$ /.

\$\bar{\mathrm{H}}\$-importance defined in [5] states that component \$i\$ is more \$\bar{\mathrm{H}}\$-important than component \$j\$ if \$\vert \overline{C}_{i}(d)\vert \geq\vert \overline{C}_{j}(d)\vert\$ for all \$d\$ Then, [5] claimed that “Clearly, more critical implies more II-important by the coupling argument.” This claim is incorrect.
Reference [5] presented Theorem 4.1, which indicates the relation of II-importance and cut-importance.
Then \$\vert \overline{C}_{i}(d, \ k)\vert =\vert \overline{C}_{j}(d, \ k)\vert\$ for all \$d\leq m\$, and all \$k\$, because each minimal cutset contributing to the k-sum is of size \$< m\$ “ [5].
Theorem 4.2 in [5] claimed that more critical implies more path-important.
Furthermore, [5] stated that Theorem 4.2 could be proved by mimicking the proof of Theorem 4.1 which is, however, not clear as we pointed out above.
Reference [5] considered the case \$p_{1}=\ldots p_{n}=p\$ to strip off the reliability part.

However, [5] did not identify the structural VF importance as \$c\$-type, and p-type, but ambiguously claimed that both \$c\$-VF important, and \$p\$- VF important implies structural \$(c-)\$ VF important.

Fig. 3:
Relations among importance indices based on minimal cutsets or pathsets. (a) Fig. 4 in [5]; (b) corrected one.
Relations among importance indices based on minimal cutsets or pathsets. (a) Fig. 4 in [5]; (b) corrected one.
Fig. 4 in [5], as shown in Fig. 3(a), summarized the relations among importance measures based on minimal cutsets or pathsets.

Because we have disproved that criticality implies \$\overline{\mathrm{H}}\$-importance, interpreted our suspicions about the relations or \$\overline{\mathrm{H}}\$-importance with cut- and path-importances, and corrected the relations among VF importance measures, we should remove the part about \$\overline{\mathrm{H}}\$-importance from Fig. 4 in [5] (see Fig. 3(a)), and revise it to be Fig. 3(b) as below.

Fig. 4 in [5], as shown in Fig. 3(a), presented the relations of cut importance with first-term importance, and path importance with rareevent importance, which is without any interpretation, and can be misleading.

links.abstract: An importance index measures the relative importance of a component in comparison to other components with respect to the system reliability. We survey many importance indices proposed in the literature, and some new ones of our own, to show how they relate. Our results can be used in two situations: 1) When components are functionally interchangeable, then more reliable units should go to the more important components. 2) When there is a fixed budget to improve the system reliability, the more ...

links.abstract: Various results concerning importance measures and rankings of system components are presented. The vectors (of component states) which appear useful in studying various component importance measures are decomposed. In particular, a new method to compute Birnbaum importance measures of components is introduced.
